author: MAHLATSE MPHAHLELE AT ORLANDO STADIUM
title: Stellenbosch launch spirited second half fight-back to stun Pirates
text:
Soccer Stellenbosch launch spirited second half fight-back to stun Pirates 29 December 2023 - 22:00 By MAHLATSE MPHAHLELE AT ORLANDO STADIUM Support independent journalism. Subscribe to our digital news package for R80 p/m. Subscribe now Deano van Rooyen of Stellenbosch fights for the ball with Karim Kimvuidi of Orlando Pirates during their DStv Premiership match at Orlando Stadium.
Image: Sydney Mahlangu/BackpagePix
Stellenbosch came from two goals down to stun Orlando Pirates 3-2 during their exciting exciting DStv Premiership clash at Orlando Stadium on Friday night.
Pirates took an early lead through goals by Tapelo Xoki and Evidence Makgopa but Stellies launched a stunning second half fightback with goals from Iqraam Rayners, Devin Titus and Andre de Jong.
As a result of this hard fought away victory, Stellenbosch, who recently won the Carling Knockout, end the year on a high and in the top half of the table with 26 points from 15 matches.
On the other hand, Pirates have dropped to the middle of the table and they may end the season on sixth if Kaizer Chiefs beat Sekhukhune United in Polokwane on Saturday.
Pirates coach Jose Riveiro started the match with Makgopa as the only player in the final Africa Cup of Nations (Afcon) squad for Bafana Bafana while Nkosinathi Sibisi started on the bench.
Broos names Bafana Bafana squad for Afcon Bafana Bafana coach Hugo Broos has named his squad that will do battle at the Africa Cup of Nations in Ivory Coast in January. Sport 1 day ago Thabang Monare and Zakhele Lepasa did not make the team while Stellenbosch coach Steve Barker started with Jayden Adams who is the only player in his team going to Afcon.
The other surprise by Riveiro was that he started exciting teenager Relebohile Mofokeng on the bench while improving Karim Kimvuidi was paired with Makgopa to lead the attack.
Pirates started on the offensive with Patrick Maswanganyi and Phillip Ndlondlo initiating most of their attacks but they were led down in the final third by Makgopa, Deon Hotto and Kimvuidi.
Stellenbosch also had their moments on the attack but the likes of Rayners, Titus and Adams could not get the better of Pirates goalkeeper Melusi Buthelezi.
Pirates took the lead after 32 minutes when defender Xoki sent Stellenbosch goalkeeper Sage Stephens the wrong way from the penalty spot after Thabelo Moloisane was handled the ball in the box.
Pirates increased their lead after 58 minutes when Makgopa produced a moment of brilliance with a cheeky back heel flick to beat Stephens after he connected with a cross from Fortune Makaringe.
â€˜Heâ€™s got our blessingsâ€™, says Safa on Fosterâ€™s reasons for skipping Afcon South African Football Association CEO Lydia Monyepao says they gave their blessings to Lyle Foster when he asked to be excused from playing for ... Sport 15 hours ago Stellenbosch launched a spirited fightback with Rayners, Devon Titus and De Jong finding the back of the net during a frantic period of the match between the 66th and 78th minutes to secure the vital three points.
For the late goals, Stellenbosch the Pirates defence that went to sleep as they completed a league double over the Buccaneers.
In the earlier kickoff on Friday, AmaZulu moved to seventh spot on the DStv Premiership standings with a dominant 3-0 win over struggling Royal AM at the Moses Mabhida Stadium in Durban.
AmaZulu, who may be kicked out of the top eight by Polokwane City, Golden Arrows or Moroka Swallows below them on the log, ensured this vital victory through first half goals by Mlondi Mbanjwa and a brace frpm Augustine Kwem.
Mbanjwa took the lead after 13 minutes and Kwem found the back of the net on the 27th and 32nd minutes to leave Royal AM in the danger zone and with a mountain to climb to revive their season.
The talking point of this match was Royal AM starting the match with club chairman Andile Mpisane who was replaced at half time as they tried to come back in the game.
Support independent journalism. Subscribe to our digital news package for R80 p/m. Subscribe now

author: stovar
title: Por falta de pago 37 hospitales en Antioquia suspenderÃ¡n la atenciÃ³n a afiliados de la Nueva EPS
text:
Por falta de pago 37 hospitales en Antioquia suspenderÃ¡n la atenciÃ³n a afiliados de la Nueva EPS
Sindicatos del sector salud denunciaron que la Nueva EPS no ha realizado pagos a 37 hospitales pÃºblicos del departamento durante el mes de diciembre. Esto ha generado una grave crisis financiera a los centros de salud, afectando su capacidad de pago.
Luis HernÃ¡n SÃ¡nchez, director de la AsociaciÃ³n de Empresas Sociales del Estado de Antioquia (EASA), informÃ³ que 37 hospitales pÃºblicos del departamento de Antioquia tomaron la decisiÃ³n de cerrar servicios de salud no urgentes a todos los usuarios, afiliados a la Nueva EPS.
SegÃºn lo explicado por SÃ¡nchez, la decisiÃ³n se tomÃ³ debido a que la Nueva EPS no ha realizado pagos a los hospitales durante el mes de diciembre, de tal modo que los hospitales se han visto perjudicados a la hora de pagar la prima de Navidad y los salarios a los funcionarios y proveedores.
No te lo pierdas:
 Primer caso grave de gripe aviar en una persona en Estados Unidos enciende las alarmas
Pese al anuncio de la suspensiÃ³n, los 37 hospitales continuarÃ¡n prestando el servicio de urgencias para garantizar la atenciÃ³n a los afiliados que lo requieran.
Conoce aquÃ­ mÃ¡s detalles.
[#ElCalentao]ğŸ¥˜ 37 hospitales en Antioquia suspenderÃ¡n la atenciÃ³n a los afiliados de la Nueva EPS debido a falta de pagos. Sindicatos del sector de la salud denuncian la falta de pagos por la EPS a los hospitales.
ğŸ™ï¸ La informaciÃ³n con Diana RÃ­os, 92.3 FM

[December 19, 2024]

author: ccoffman
title: Physics, math undergrad Isa Fite named a 2024 Goldwater Scholar
text: The University of Tulsa is pleased to announce that Maria Isabelle â€œIsaâ€ Fite, a second-year student majoring in [physics](https://utulsa.edu/academics/health-natural-sciences/departments/physics-engineering-physics/) and applied [math](https://utulsa.edu/academics/engineering-computer-science/departments/mathematics/) from Tulsa, Oklahoma, has been awarded a [2024 Barry Goldwater Scholarship](https://goldwaterscholarship.gov/). This prestigious award recognizes exceptional undergraduates studying science, engineering, and/or math disciplines. â€œThe Goldwater Scholarship provides a level of respect in the scientific community,â€ said Fite, one of only 508 college students in the United States to receive the award this year. â€œWe are enormously proud of Isa and her accomplishments,â€ said TU President Brad R. Carson. â€œThe University of Tulsaâ€™s science, technology, engineering, and math programs are highly regarded. We also root all students in the arts and humanities to ensure well-rounded alumni and offer an enlightening Honors College experience that attracts students of Isaâ€™s caliber.â€ Fite thanked her faculty mentors, Applied Professor of Physics [Jerry McCoy](https://utulsa.edu/people/jerry-mccoy/) and Warren Foundation Chair in Bioinformatics [Brett McKinney](https://utulsa.edu/people/brett-mckinney/), a theoretical physicist, for setting her up for success. As a high school student, she attended TUâ€™s monthly [Physics Journal Club](https://utulsa.edu/news/common-passion-unites-diverse-minds-in-physics-journal-club/) meetings, organized by McCoy. He invited her to participate in an independent study of particle physics. When Fite was just 17, she was sitting in on research presentations by TU seniors and was thrilled to find that the university students and faculty took her seriously despite the fact that she had not yet finished high school. â€œI took note of the understanding Isa displayed in discussing physics concepts such as wave-particle duality and Heisenbergâ€™s uncertainty principle, even though she had not yet taken foundational coursework in these areas,â€ McCoy said. â€œShe frequently goes well beyond efforts other students might make to understand a subject. For example â€¦ she currently takes classes in German out of a desire to read Heisenberg, Einstein, Minkowski, and others in their original language. â€œAs Isa continues to challenge her intellectual gifting, she will distinguish herself as one of the very brightest â€“ if not the brightest â€“ students with whom I have had the privilege to work.â€ While she applied to other prestigious universities, Fite said, â€œTU was the best place I could have been,â€ citing the relationships she has developed with faculty and graduate students and the opportunities to excel in her chosen field. Upon arriving on campus in fall 2022, Fite joined the [Tulsa Undergraduate Research Challenge](https://utulsa.edu/research/research-opportunities/turc/) (TURC) to formally begin pursuing her academic dreams. â€œThe TURC program was instrumental,â€ she said. â€œIsabelle joined my research group at the end of her first year to start dabbling in quantum theory, and before I knew it, she was contributing to real theoretical physics problems. She is currently working on a manuscript describing a method for calculating the properties of vortices in Bose-Einstein condensates in D dimensions. Next, we plan to use this model to study black holes,â€ McKinney said. â€œIt has been a joy to mentor Isabelle, a most deserving Goldwater Scholar.â€ Fite serves as the Oxley College of Health & Natural Scienceâ€™ delegate to the TURC Student Advisory Committee, advising administrators on policies and events from a student perspective as well as helping plan TURC events. She is a member of the TU Honors Program and president of the universityâ€™s Wesley Foundation Student Council. Fite also thanked Terrie Shipley, TUâ€™s director of national fellowships, for assisting with the rigorous Goldwater application process. The university, which this year is home to the most National Merit Scholars per capita, devotes significant resources to ensuring high-achieving students have excellent support to reach their goals. After graduation, Fite plans to pursue a doctorate in theoretical physics. Her goal is to use pure mathematics to conduct research on the intersection of quantum mechanics and gravitational physics.

author: Lecia Bushak
title: â€˜We beat Big Pharmaâ€™: President Biden, Bernie Sanders tout drug pricing reform
text:
Drug pricing will remain a key issue throughout the 2024 presidential campaign and President Joe Biden is already starting to hit the topic hard to gain favor with voters.
To that end, Biden teamed with Sen. Bernie Sanders, (I-VT), on Wednesday to outline the White Houseâ€™s latest drug pricing reform accomplishments.
The partnership of one-time Democratic presidential rivals also served as a push from the partyâ€™s leading voices to implement additional policies aimed at lowering drug costs even further.
Front and center at the joint press conference was the recent decision by several major drugmakers â€” including AstraZeneca, GSK and Boehringer Ingelheim â€” to cap their inhalers at $35 a month starting in June.
The manufacturers announced the move after Sanders led a group of Senate Democrats in
writing a letter to pharma CEOs in January, demanding they lower the cost of inhalers for people with asthma and other respiratory conditions.
Last month, AstraZeneca CEO Pascal Soriot noted in a statement that the drugmaker agreed to cap the cost of inhalers to build on its commitment to address barriers to access and affordability for patients living with respiratory diseases.
â€œWe remain dedicated to addressing the need for affordability of our medicines, but the system is complex and we cannot do it alone,â€ Soriot added. â€œIt is critical that Congress bring together key stakeholders to help reform the healthcare system so patients can afford the medicines they need, not just today, but for the future.â€
In his speech, Biden pointed out that an inhaler costs $49 in the U.K., compared to $645 in the U.S.
â€œThe last few weeks, some of the big drug companies have gotten the message to reduce the prices for some asthma drugs,â€ Biden said. â€œThereâ€™s some progress going onâ€¦ But itâ€™s about time.â€
Democrats united against healthcare costs
Four years after Biden and Sanders ran against one another in the Democratic primaries in 2020, the two have put their differences aside to push an issue that has become increasingly bipartisan â€” the high cost of healthcare in the U.S.
Sanders, who heads the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (HELP) committee, made
drug pricing one of his top priorities during the past year.
Recently, he threatened to subpeona the CEOs of Johnson & Johnson and Merck in order to get them to testify in Congress about high drug costs.
â€œOur nation is politically divided â€” nobody doubts that,â€ Sanders said in his remarks. â€œBut there is one issue that the American people â€” whether they are Republicans, Democrats, or Independents; whether theyâ€™re conservative or progressive â€” are united on. And that is that we are sick and tired of paying by far the highest prices in the world for prescription drugs.â€
Did Biden beat Big Pharma?
Following Sandersâ€™ comments, Biden proceeded to claim victory over Big Pharma, noting that he was proud his administration has taken on the pharma industry â€œin the most significant ways ever.â€
â€œ[Bernie] and I have been fighting this for 25 years,â€ Biden said. â€œFinally, we beat Big Pharma. Finally.â€
While total victory over the pharma industry may be an exaggeration, the Biden administration was responsible for what was arguably the most significant drug pricing reform in years â€” the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) â€” in 2022.
The IRAâ€™s drug pricing provisions included giving Medicare the power to negotiate the prices of certain Part D drugs, as well as capping the cost of insulin for Medicare beneficiaries at $35 a month.
This year, the Medicare negotiation process kicked off, with all pharma companies of the first 10 drugs selected agreeing to participate in the program.
In February, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
set its initial price offers for those 10 drugs â€” and negotiations with drugmakers will determine a maximum fair price by August 1.
Earlier this week, the Biden administration said it has responded to offers from the manufacturers of the drugs selected for pricing negotiations, but provided no details.
The new drug prices for the 10 drugs â€” including therapies manufactured by Johnson & Johnson, Merck and Bristol Myers Squibb â€” will go into effect in 2026.
Next year, the federal government is set to choose another 15 drugs to have their prices negotiated by Medicare.
Biden backs IRAâ€™s impact
In his speech, Biden emphasized that the Medicare negotiation program is slated to reduce the federal deficit by $160 billion â€” adding that his administration will attempt to increase the number of negotiated drugs to 50 per year.
â€œI think we should be more aggressive,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s time to negotiate lower prices for at least 50 drugs a year. [I]f we move that number up, weâ€™ll save taxpayers another $200 billion on top of the $160 billion, because Medicare will not be paying these exorbitant costs.â€
Whether the program will save patients money, however, is still up in the air.
Biden went on to argue that while he was a capitalist, he believes capitalism without competition isnâ€™t capitalism, calling it â€œexploitation.â€ He also singled out efforts by the pharma industry to stifle generic competition in order to preserve profits for brand name drugs.
â€œWhen Big Pharma doesnâ€™t play by the rules, competitors canâ€™t offer lower prices for generic drugs and devices that carry medication, so prices are raised artificially,â€ Biden said. â€œI thank Bernie for leading the charge to do something about this.â€
Biden also touted recent efforts by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to crack down on the pharma industry, including targeting sham patents in the Food and Drug Administrationâ€™s so-called â€œOrange Book.â€
In the last year, the FTC has pinpointed several Big Pharma companies over their
wrongfully listed patents that can contribute to higher prices and undermine generic competition.
